text: A cylinder has a radius of 5 cm and a height of 12 cm.
The area of the base of the cylinder is 5 x 5 x π cm2, so the volume of the cylinder is 5 x 5 x π x 12 = 300π cm3 (or about 942 cm3).
• Which change in the dimensions of the cylinder would cause the greater change in volume: doubling the height or doubling the radius?

Doubling the radius. If you double the height, it will be 24 cm. Then, the volume will be 5 x 5 x p x 24 = 600p cm3.

If you double the radius, it will be 10 cm. Then, the volume will be 10 x 10 x p x 12 = 1200p cm3, which is bigger than 600p.
• By what factor is the volume increased if both the radius and the height are increased by a factor of 2? By a factor of 3? Explain.

When the radius of a cylinder is r and its height is h, then the volume of the cylinder is r × r × h × π. If the radius increases by 2 and the height increases by 2, then the volume will be 2r × 2r × π × 2h = 8× r × r × h × π. This is 8 (or 23) times bigger than the original cylinder. If the radius increases by 3 and the height increases by 3, then the volume will be 3r × 3r × π × 3h = 27× r × r × h × π. This is 27 (or 33) times bigger than the original cylinder.
